section.title: Defining a topology

statement.p: Let X be a set, and let \mc T\subseteq \mc P(X) satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: If \mc U\subseteq\mc T, then \bigcup\mc U\in\mc T.
If U,V\in\mc T, then U\cap V\in\mc T.

statement.p: Then \mc T is called a topology on X, the pair \tuple{X,\mc T} is called a topological space, and elements U\in\mc T are called open sets of the space. (Usually \tuple{X,\mc T} is abbreviated to just X when the topology is known from context.)

statement.p: Let X be any set. Then the following sets are topologies on X.

ol.li: \mc T=\mc P(X) is called the discrete topology.
\mc T=\{\emptyset,X\} is called the indiscrete topology.

statement.p: Let \mc T be a topology, and let \mc U\subseteq\mc T be finite. Then \bigcap\mc U\in\mc T.
Suppose D\subseteq X and \cl D = X. Then D is said to be dense in X.

A subset is dense if and only if it intersects every nonempty open set.
A subset is dense if and only if every point of the space belongs to it or is a limit point of it. (Corollaries also don't show up in slides according to the docinfo though.)
